page.title: 18RODNEY STOKE NATURE RESERVE
page.content: Many plant species exist in this Reserve. Ash is the dominant woodland species but oak and hazel are common; lime, elm, field maple and whitebeam also occur as well as species of introduced trees such as sycamore, larch and Norway spruce. A wide variety of plant habitats exist; ferns and mosses are common in shady, rocky conditions, but in peripheral fields careful management allows orchids, clovers, trefoils and vetches to flourish. 30 species of butterfly have been identified and badgers are common along with foxes, bats and rabbits. 72 species of bird are recorded of which 27 breed within the Reserve. Grazing and cutting of pasture and scrub as well as thinning of woodland are deliberately practised to encourage natural regeneration.
